message_1: Consider the formula P->(Q->R), where P, Q, and R are propositions. Using linear logic, prove that ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R) is a valid formula.
message_2:
To prove that ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R) is a valid formula in linear logic, we will use the sequent calculus for linear logic. We will show that the sequent ⊢ ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R) is provable.

Recall that in linear logic, the ⊸ (linear implication) connective is defined as A⊸B = !A -o B, where !A is the exponential modality (of course) and -o is the linear implication. We will use the following rules for the sequent calculus:

1. Axiom rule: A ⊢ A
2. Cut rule: If Γ ⊢ A and Δ, A ⊢ B, then Γ, Δ ⊢ B
3. Linear implication introduction: If Γ, A ⊢ B, then Γ ⊢ A⊸B
4. Linear implication elimination: If Γ ⊢ A⊸B and Δ ⊢ A, then Γ, Δ ⊢ B
5. Exponential modality introduction: If Γ ⊢ A, then Γ ⊢ !A
6. Exponential modality elimination: If Γ, A ⊢ B, then Γ, !A ⊢ B

Now, let's prove the sequent ⊢ ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R):

1. ⊢ P⊸Q (axiom rule)
2. ⊢ Q⊸R (axiom rule)
3. P⊸Q, Q ⊢ R (linear implication elimination on 2)
4. P⊸Q, Q⊸R ⊢ R (cut rule on 1 and 3)
5. P⊸Q ⊢ Q⊸R⊸R (linear implication introduction on 4)
6. ⊢ (P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R)⊸R (linear implication introduction on 5)
7. ⊢ P⊸R (cut rule on 6 and 2)
8. ⊢ ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R) (linear implication introduction on 7)

Thus, we have shown that ((P⊸Q)⊸(Q⊸R))⊸(P⊸R) is a valid formula in linear logic.
